ygData.subject: Wave Generator Experiment / Mackey-Glass Series
ygData.msgSnippet: My initial function approximation experiment tried to approximate y=f(x) by feeding values of x and comparing an ANN s output with the expected output. So the

Subject: Wave Generator Experiment / Mackey-Glass Series
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=127853030; y=knlPNycGHswMN24rPkpeoP90bgBttfF-meHHeg6fvPUymYKQlrl6
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

My initial function approximation experiment tried to approximate y=f(x) 
by feeding values of x and comparing an ANN's output with the expected 
output. So the ANN is mapping x directly to y.

I decided to experiment with an alternative technique whereby there is 
no input and I use the ANN as a sort of wave generator. I activate the 
network and take a reading and repeat this as many times as I want. I 
can then match the outputs against an expected output and hopefully 
evolve ANNs that can generate a continuous wave form.

This does seem to work to some extent, e.g. I can evolve sine wave 
generators easily enough, and a square wave approximation has a lot of 
rough edges and noise but the overall shape is there. So I decided to 
try something a bit more challenging, specifically the Mackey-Glass 
series, which can be made to generate a chaotic waveform. Here's were I 
noticed the first problem.

If I use a low sampling rate then the output from the series rises and 
falls within just a few activations of my ANN's and they can do a 
reasonably good job of tracking the function over short periods (I 
haven't tried anything too long yet). If however I increase the sampling 
rate then there may be many activations between rises and falls, but the 
kind of small networks that I start out with when I initiase a run have 
a very fast oscilaltion rate (or high natural frequency) due to their 
small size and compact interconnections. I suppose I could try and start 
with a population of pre-built networks with a lower oscillation rate, 
but I don't think this is a solution for the general case where a 
function may have many different harmonics.

Anyway to give you an idea of the kind of results I've been getting 
here's a link to a graph showing a short section of a mackey-glass 
waveform in black and an approximation in red. The training data is 
shown on the first third of the graph up until the black line drops to 
zero, the remaining two thirds show the network's response beyond the 
training data.

http://tinypic.com/fdhssg.png

The graph shows the network generating a fairly regular output that 
roughly matches the black line, but there is no or very little matching 
of the subtle variations. The low-res approximations I tried were 
generally better matching waveforms.

Colin.
